chapter: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: A patient presented with a deformity as shown in the image below. What is this deformityknown as?
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: In which of the following patients will you not expect a saddle nose deformity?

options.A: A VDRL positive patient with gumma of the nasal septum
options.B: A patient with lateral madarosis and leonine facies
options.C: A boxer who developed bilateral nasal obstruction after a trauma to the nose
options.D: A patient with growth hormone excess and a large nose.

questions.explanation: Option D is a case of acromegaly, in which there may be enlargement of the nose. Saddle nosedeformity only occurs when the bridge of the nose collapses.Causes for saddle nose/depressed dorsum of nose:• Nasal trauma causing depressed fractures - most common etiology.• Excessive removal of septum in submucous resection•• Destruction of septal cartilage by haematoma or abscess•• Leprosy•⚫ Syphilis⚫ Tuberculosis.•Option A is a case of tertiary syphilis.Option B is a case of lepromatous leprosy.Option C is a case of septal hematoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: 339A newborn developed respiratory distress immediately after delivery. The paediatrician wasunable to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares. Which of the followingstatements is false about the above diagnosis?

options.A: It is due to persistence of bucconasal membrane
options.B: Can be associated with CHARGE syndrome.
options.C: Bony obstruction is more common than membranous obstruction.
options.D: Immediate tracheostomy to be done to maintain the airway.

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of bilateral choanal atresia and immediate tracheostomyis not indicated.Simply securing a feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway and forces theinfant to breathe through the mouth. This is known as McGovern's technique and obviates theneed for tracheostomy.349OMARROW
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: What is the most common presentation of a patient with the pathology shown in the CTbelow?
questions.explanation: Neonates with bilateral choanal atresia (image) present with respiratory distress at birth.Neonates are natural nose breathers, and do not breathe from their mouths.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Choanal atresia is not associated with which of the following defects?
questions.explanation: Choanal atresia may be associated with CHARGE syndrome. Renal angiomyolipoma is not a partof CHARGE syndrome.• C- Coloboma of the eye•H- Heart defects• A- Atresia of the choana•R- Retarded growth and development• G- Genital anomalies.• E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.Renal angiomyolipoma - It is one of the major features of tuberous sclerosis complex.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: A 2-year-old child was brought with a soft, compressible swelling at the root of the nose.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario of isolated solitary mass arising from the root of the nose should raisethe index of suspicion of nasal meningocele or meningoencephalocele. It is the herniation of braintissue along with its meninges through a congenital bony defect.350Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. It presents as a cystic, bluish, compressible,translucent mass at the root of the nose (nasofrontal variety), side of the nose (nasoethmoidvariety), or at the anteromedial aspect of the orbit (nasoorbital variety).Furstenberg's test: compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes anencephalocele to enlarge.Investigation: CT or MRI.Treatment: Transnasal endoscopic excision with the closure of the defect using bone or cartilagegraft along with temporalis fascia and fat.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Which of the following statements about nasal glioma is false?
questions.explanation: There is no CSF leakage in nasal glioma. It is a nipped-off portion of an encephalocele with nocommunication with the cranial cavity.They usually present as a firm, subcutaneous swelling causing nasal obstruction.-Furstenberg's test compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes anencephalocele to enlarge, but not a glioma. So, this test is negative in nasal glioma.60% of nasal gliomas are extra-nasal, 30% are intranasal, and 10% are both intranasal andextra-nasal.CT scan reveals bony details while MRI reveals soft tissue details of a nasal glioma.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: A surgeon suspects a rodent ulcer in a patient who presented with a finding as shown in the image. What is this condition also called?

options.B: Squamous cell carcinoma, Basal cell carcinoma
options.C: It is commonly seen in middle-aged women
options.D: It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands

questions.explanation: Basal cell carcinoma, also known as rodent ulcer, is the most common malignant tumor involving the skin of the nose.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: A patient presented with atrophic dry nasal mucosa, extensive crustations, and a woody hardexternal nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma.Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).It has 3 stages:•Atrophic stage- Crusting and foul smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.• Granulomatous stage- Painless, non ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermalinfiltration giving feel of woody/hebra nose.• Cicatricial stage- Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. Deformity is calledtapir nose.THE XIV.Option A: Atrophic rhinitis doesn't cause woody nose.Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents asswelling over tip of nose.352Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi andpresents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: A pathologist observed Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies on microscopy in a biopsy specimentaken from the nose. Which of the following is a false statement regarding the diagnosis?

options.B: Medical management include streptomycin and tetracycline.
options.C: Surgery is the treatment of choice for this disease

questions.explanation: Biopsy findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell's bodies are characteristic findings inrhinoscleroma. Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity.Biopsy in the case of rhinoscleroma shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells,lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies.Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containingcausative bacilli.Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. Theyoccur due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells.H&E showing a mixture of plasma cells (arrow), lymphocytes (short arrow), Miculikz cellswhich are vacuolated macrophages containing causative bacilli (double arrow).Option A: Rhinoscleroma is endemic in several parts of the world. In India, it is seen more oftenin the northern than in the southern parts.Option D: Organism can be cultured from biopsy material.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Snuffles are seen in which stage of syphilis?
questions.explanation: Snuffles are seen in early congenital syphilis. Nasal features in different stages of syphilis: Stage - Early congenital syphilis: Snuffles, Late congenital syphilis: Gumma on the nasal septum, Primary syphilis: Primary chancre of the vestibule of nose, Secondary syphilis: Simple rhinitis with crusting and fissuring in the nasal vestibule, Tertiary form of acquired syphilis: Gumma on the nasal septum
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: An eighteen-year-old boy presented with a lesion over the nose as shown in the image. Whatis your diagnosis?343
questions.explanation: The image shows apple jelly nodules seen in lupus vulgaris which is a low-grade tuberculousinfection.These are brown, gelatinous nodules commonly affecting nasal vestibule or the skin of nose andface.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Given below is a histological section of a biopsy taken from a farmer who presented with avascular polypoidal mass protruding from his left nostril. What is the causative organism forthis condition?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario along with the histology (showing sporangia) is suggestive ofrhinosporidiosis caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi.Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Rhinosporidium seeberi belongs to which group of organisms?
questions.explanation: Rhinosporidium seeberi is an aquatic protista.Molecular biological techniques have demonstrated that this organism is an aquatic protistanparasite and it is currently included in a new class, the Mesomycetozoea, along with organismscausing similar infections in amphibians and fish.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: A farmer presented with a mass protruding from his right nostril as shown in the figure below. On examination, the mass bleeds easily on touch. Which of the statements is false regarding the diagnosis?

options.A: Waterborne is the most common route of transmission
options.B: Endemic in southern states of India

questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: A man who works in a cattle ranch presented with complaints of a mass protruding from the left nostril and blood-stained nasal discharge. The mass is pink, leafy, and polypoidal and is attached to the nasal septum. Biopsy from the lesion showed several sporangia. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.explanation: Surgical management (excision of the lesion with cauterization of the base) is always the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis. No drug treatment has proved effective, although dapsone is tried in some cases. Follow-up of the patient after surgical management is necessary, as recurrence is common.
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about nasal T-cell lymphoma?

options.A: It is also known as Stewart's granulomas
options.C: It is a locally invasive tumor.
options.D: Surgery is the treatment of choice

questions.explanation: T-cell lymphoma is treated by radiation when it is localised and by chemotherapy when it isdisseminated.The condition is also called as:• Non-healing midline granuloma•⚫ Midline granulomas reticulosis• Stewart's granuloma• Nasal T-cell lymphoma• Lethal midline granulomaIt is associated with EBV. Cells express T cell markers like CD56.Nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the presenting features. Destruction of mid-facial structuresmay be caused by the local invasion.Histologically, polymorphic lymphoid tissue with angiocentric and angioinvasive features areseen.355
questions.chapter_heading: Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose
